Description: THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT HIV/STD AND TB PREVENTION AND TREATMENT IN THE RMI - PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY THE REPUBLIC OF THE MARSHALL ISLANDS (RMI) IS A SMALL NATION BURDENED HEAVILY WITH COMMUNICABLE DISEASES. VARIOUS STUDIES SHOW THAT ALTHOUGH RMI HAS LOW HIV PREVALENCE RATE, TUBERCULOSIS (TB) AND SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED DISEASES (STDS) ARE ON THE RISE AND CONTINUE TO RISE EACH DAY. WITH LIMITED MAN POWER, LIMITED HEALTH STAFF CAPACITY REGARDING COMMUNICABLE DISEASES CONTINUES TO BE A PROBLEM. A SMALL COUNTRY SUCH AS THE RMI’S PURPOSE IS TO CONTINUE TO SEEK FINANCIAL AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE IN ORDER TO FIGHT THE RISE OF COMMUNICABLE DISEASES IN THE ISLANDS. FOR THIS 5-YEAR FUNDING CYCLE (INITIATING IN 2023), THE RMI PROGRAM COLLABORATION AND SERVICE INTEGRATION (PCSI), WHICH COMPRISES OF HIV/STD/TB & VIRAL HEPATITIS PROGRAMS SEEK TO CONTINUE TO REACH TARGET AND VULNERABLE POPULATION FOR TESTING, SCREENING AND TREATMENT PURPOSES. TARGET POPULATIONS INCLUDE: MSM, TRANS GENDERS, PERSONS WHO INJECT DRUGS (PWID), COMMERCIAL SEX WORKERS, PREGNANT WOMEN, AND PERSONS VULNERABLE TO TB INFECTIONS.

ACCELERATING THE PREVENTION AND CONTROL OF HIV, VIRAL HEPATITIS, STDS, AND TB IN THE U.S. AFFILIATED PACIFIC ISLANDS - THE U.S.-AFFILIATED PACIFIC ISLANDS (USAPIS) EXPERIENCE UNIQUE, SIGNIFICANT CHALLENGES WITH PREVENTION AND CONTROL OF HIV, VH, STIS AND TB DUE TO A MULTITUDE OF FACTORS INCLUDING, AMONG OTHERS, REMOTELY DISPERSED POPULATIONS, A LIMITED UNDERSTANDING OF DISEASE BURDEN, AND ANTIQUATED AND FRAGMENTED SURVEILLANCE, LABORATORY AND OVERALL HEALTHCARE SYSTEMS.  IN TURN, THESE FACTORS PLACE LIMITS ON THE ACCESSIBILITY TO AND THE PROVISION OF CRITICAL SERVICES INCLUDING THE EARLY DETECTION AND TREATMENT OF DISEASES.  MOREOVER, THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC HAS HIGHLIGHTED THE NEED FOR URGENT SYSTEMIC CHANGES TO THESE SYSTEMS.  THE BURDEN OF HIV, STIS, VIRAL HEPATITIS AND TUBERCULOSIS IN GUAM CONTINUES TO DISPROPORTIONATELY IMPACT SPECIFIC GROUPS. THE PROJECT HAS EXPERIENCE IN ALL THE FOCUS AREAS OF HIV, STI, VIRAL HEPATITIS, AND TUBERCULOSIS.  IN ADDITION, THE PROJECT HAS MADE CONSIDERABLE PROGRESS THROUGH THE SUPPORT MADE POSSIBLE VIACDC-RFA-PS13-1301 AND CDC-RFA-PS18-1801 NOFOS.  THIS APPLICATION BUILDS ON THE PROGRESS MADE FROM THE PREVIOUS NOFOS TO INCREASE THE PROGRAM COLLABORATION AND SERVICE INTEGRATION (PCSI) ACROSS STI, HIV, VIRAL HEPATITIS, AND TB PROGRAM AREAS TO IMPROVE THE EFFICIENT USE OF RESOURCES, REDUCE HEALTH-RELATED DISPARITIES THROUGH WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT THROUGH TRAINING AND SKILLS DEVELOPMENT AND INCREASING ACCESS TO SCREENING, TESTING, AND LINKAGE TO CARE FOR POPULATIONS DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTED BY HIV, VH, STIS AND TB.  LASTLY, IT IS THE PROJECT'S INTENT TO SUPPORT THE IDENTIFICATION OF PRIORITIES AND BEST PRACTICES FOR ADDRESSING SOCIAL FACTORS THAT DISPROPORTIONATELY INCREASE RISK FOR HIV, VH, STIS AND TB AND TO PROMOTE HEALTH EQUITY.

TO ACCELERATE THE PREVENTION AND CONTROL OF HIV, VIRAL HEPATITIS, SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED DISEASE AND TUBERCULOSIS IN THE FEDERATED STATES OF MICRONESIA AND U.S. AFFILIATED PACIFIC ISLANDS - ACCELERATING THE PREVENTION AND CONTROL OF HIV, VIRAL HEPATITIS, STD AND TUBERCULOSIS IN THE FEDERATED STATES OF MICRONESIA IS A PRIORITY AS THESE FOUR FOCUSED DISEASE AREAS ARE STILL MAJOR HEALTH ISSUES IN THE COUNTRY. ALTHOUGH HIV CASES ARE LOW, STD RATES FOR CHLAMYDIA REMAINS HIGH AT 23% DURING 2018 AND DECREASED TO 16% DURING COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE PROGRAM COLLABORATION AND SERVICE INTEGRATION PROJECT WITH ITS 4 STRATEGIES HAD IMPROVED THE EFFECTIVENESS OF PROGRAM IMPLEMENTATION AND SERVICE DELIVERY. THE COLLABORATION OF PROGRAMS WILL CONTINUE TO LEAD THE IMPROVEMENT IN PATIENT CARE AND MANAGEMENT FOR MULTIPLE DISEASES. THIS PROGRAM COLLABORATION AND SERVICE INTEGRATION IS APPROPRIATE AND EFFECTIVE FOR AREAS WITH GEOGRAPHIC AND LIMITED HUMAN RESOURCE CHALLENGES; ADDITIONALLY, CROSS TRAINING OF STAFF WILL ALSO LEAD TO INCREASED KNOWLEDGE IN MULTIPLE DISEASES. THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT AND STREAMLINE INTEGRATED INTERVENTIONS LEADING TO DECREASING RATES OF DISEASES THROUGH IMPROVED PATIENT TREATMENT OUTCOMES, CONTACT TRACING AND PARTNER SERVICES.  DATA MANAGEMENT AND DISEASE SURVEILLANCE WILL IMPROVE THE DECISION MAKING FROM HIGHER MANAGEMENT AND GUIDE THE PROGRAMS IN THE USE OF FUNDING SOURCES.

CNMI CHCC PCSI PROGRAM - THE COMMONWEALTH OF THE NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS (CNMI) POPULATION HEALTH SERVICES (PHS) AS PART OF THE COMMONWEALTH HEALTHCARE CORPORATION (CHCC) IS DEPENDENT ON U.S. FEDERAL GOVERNMENT FUNDING AND SUPPORTS TO ADMINISTER COMPREHENSIVE HIV/AIDS, STDS, VIRAL HEPATITIS, TB AND HANSEN’S DISEASE PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE PROGRAMS WITHIN THE CNMI.  AS THE SOLE PUBLIC HEALTH INSTITUTION FOR THE COMMONWEALTH, THE CHCC POPULATION HEALTH SERVICES’ OBJECTIVES ARE TO REDUCE NEW INFECTIONS, IMPROVE ACCESS TO CARE, ADVANCE THE HEALTH AND WELL-BEING OF PEOPLE INFECTED AND AFFECTED, TO REDUCE STIGMA ASSOCIATED WITH THESE DISEASES, AND PROMOTE HEALTH EQUITY. THE PROGRAM SUBMITS THIS APPLICATION FOR THE CONTINUED SUPPORT OF THE PROJECTS AND OBJECTIVES INITIATED BY CDC-RFA-PS13-1301 AND CDC-RFA-PS18-1801.  THE INTEGRATED FIVE-YEAR AWARD BEGINNING IN 2013 FUNDED THE CNMI  TO 1) ENHANCE EXISTING STRENGTHS/ONGOING EFFORTS, 2) IDENTIFY AREAS FOR IMPROVEMENT WITHIN HEALTH CARE SYSTEMS, 3) IMPROVE INTER/INTRA-AGENCY COLLABORATION, AND 4) INCREASE EFFICIENCIES OF HEALTH CARE SYSTEMS’ ABILITIES TO DIAGNOSIS, TREAT AND PREVENT HIV, VIRAL HEPATITIS, STDS, TB AND HANSEN’S DISEASE WITHIN THEIR JURISDICTIONS.  THIS APPLICATION INTENDS TO FULFILL IMPLEMENTATION OF THE FIVE CORE STRATEGIES IN THE FOA: 1.	PROGRAM COLLABORATION AND SERVICE INTEGRATION (PCSI) 2.	SURVEILLANCE, DATA MANAGEMENT, AND REPORTING 3.	WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT 4.	LABORATORY STRENGTHENING 5.	DISEASE -SPECIFIC PREVENTION AND CARE  THE CNMI CHCC PHS CONTINUES ITS SUPPORT OF THE NATIONAL CENTER FOR HIV/AIDS, VIRAL HEPATITIS, STD, AND TB PREVENTION (NCHHSTP) PROGRAM IMPERATIVE FOR IMPROVED INTEGRATED PREVENTION AND TREATMENT SERVICES FROM THE  PROGRAM LEVEL THAT ULTIMATELY SERVES TO IMPROVE CLIENT LEVEL SERVICES.  THERE IS COMMITMENT FROM THE PROGRAMS TO INCREASE EFFECTIVENESS, PREPAREDNESS, AND IMPROVE OPERATIONS SUPPORTED BY DISEASE-SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS FROM THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION (CDC), AND NATIONAL STRATEGIC PLANS SUCH AS HEALTHY PEOPLE 2030, THE U.S. NATIONAL HIV/AIDS STRATEGY, THE U.S. GOVERNMENT GLOBAL TUBERCULOSIS STRATEGY, AND THE GUIDELINES FOR THE INVESTIGATION OF CONTACTS OF PERSONS WITH INFECTIOUS TUBERCULOSIS.  THE COLLABORATION OF THE PROGRAMS TO INTEGRATE SERVICES THROUGH SURVEILLANCE AND DATA MANAGEMENT WILL PROVIDE THE INFRASTRUCTURE TO STRENGTHEN HEALTH SYSTEMS FOR IMPROVED HEALTH OUTCOMES FOR THE TARGET POPULATIONS.

ASDOH HIV/STD/VH/TB PREVENTION & CONTROL PROGRAM - THE U.S TERRITORY OF AMERICAN SAMOA PROVIDES WRAP-AROUND, COMPREHENSIVE PREVENTION SERVICES AND EARLY INTERVENTION FOR HIV, STD, VH, AND TB THROUGH THE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH. ALTHOUGH OUR INCIDENCE RATES CONTINUE TO RISE, THERE IS A SIGNIFICANT NEED TO CONTINUE TO PROVIDE PREVENTION AND EARLY INTERVENTION SERVICES TO ENSURE DISEASE MANAGEMENT AND CONTINUITY OF CARE. HIGHER NUMBERS OF IMMIGRANTS FROM DIFFERENT PARTS OF THE WORLD MIGRATE TO AMERICAN SAMOA AND INCREASES THE THREAT OF HIV EXPOSURE AND A HIGHER INCIDENCE OF HIV ON THE ISLAND. THE CURRENT ZERO-PREVALENCE DATA AND CASES OF AIDS DETERMINE HIGH RISK GROUPS IN WHICH WE TARGET FOR STD, TB AND HEPATITIS B TESTING AND TREATMENT. ASDOH AND THE LBJ MEDICAL CENTER ARE COMMITTED TO SERVING THE HEALTH NEEDS OF AMERICAN SAMOA AND PREVENTING STD, HIV, TB, AND VH INFECTIONS. BY DOING SO, WE OPERATE TESTING IN A VARIETY OF CLINICS AND THE HOSPITAL TO SCREEN AND TREAT.  ASDOH IS FOCUSED ON STRENGTHENING THEIR EFFORTS IN STD, HIV, TB AND VH PREVENTION THROUGH ITS MULTI-PURPOSE PROGRAM AND ACTIVITIES CENTERED TO CONTROL EFFORTS THROUGH ESTABLISHING EFFECTIVE PARTNERSHIPS, MOBILIZING NECESSARY RESOURCES AND ENSURING QUALITY DIAGNOSTIC AND TREATMENT SERVICES UNDER DOTS STRATEGY.  THE ASDOH IS IN ALIGNMENT WITH THE CDC LOGIC MODEL TO INTEGRATE PUBLIC HEALTH STRATEGIES APPROVED BY THE CDC TO 1) IMPROVE OUR EFFORTS IN INTEGRATIONS, 2) STREAMLINING ADMINISTRATION AND REPORTING, 3) STRENGTHENING OUR HEALTH DEPARTMENT, 4) PROVIDING PREVENTION AND TREATMENT SERVICES, BY UTILIZING THIS MULTIPRONGED APPROACH WE ARE SEEKING TO DECREASE THE INCIDENCE OF HIV, STDS, TB AND VH, COLLECT DATA IN AN EFFECTIVE WAY TO DETERMINE QUALITY IMPROVEMENTS, PROVIDING TRAININGS FOR THE STAFF TO STAY UP TO DATE WITH NEW INNOVATIONS TO CONDUCT SERVICES. LASTLY, THE PROGRAM WILL CONTINUE TO PROVIDE SCREENING AND TREATMENT FOR HIV, STDS, TB/LTBI, AND VH FOR MSM, TRANSGENDER, CSW, PWID, PREGNANT WOMEN, AND RACIAL AND ETHNIC MINORITY POPULATIONS. BY TARGETING THE INDIVIDUALS AT GREATEST RISK AND DIRECTING OUR RESOURCES TO THESE COMMUNITIES, WE WILL BE ABLE TO PROVIDE THE MOST COMPREHENSIVE, WRAP-AROUND SERVICES TO THOSE IN HIGHEST NEED. THESE MULTIPRONGED EFFORTS WILL LEAD TO A HEALTHIER AND DISEASE FREE COMMUNITY.  THE ASDOH WILL PROVIDE REGULAR DATA MANAGEMENT AND QUALITY ASSURANCE ACTIVITIES TO ENSURE FIDELITY OF EACH PROGRAM. THE EVALUATION OF PROGRAM ACTIVITIES TO AND OUTCOME MEASURES WILL DETERMINE THE STRATEGIES AND QUALITY IMPROVEMENT MEASURES THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE WORK WE CONTINUE TO DO.

ACCELERATING THE PREVENTION AND CONTROL OF HIV, VIRAL HEPATITIS, STDS AND TB IN US AFFILIATED PACIFIC ISLANDS - REPUBLIC OF PALAU THROUGH THIS FUNDING AND SUPPORT WILL BE ABLE TO CONTINUE TO STRENGTHEN OUR ABILITIES TO PROVIDE NEEDED SERVICES, PREVENTION AND INTERVENTION OF HIV, VIRAL HEPATITS, STDS AND TB FOR OUR POPULATION.  IT WILL ENABLE ROP TO EXPAND, IMPROVE AND SCALE UP EFFORTS IN PREVENTING, CONTROLLING AND ELIMINATING HIV, VIRAL HEPATITIS, STDS AND TB IN PALAU AND THE REGION.  THROUGH THIS PROJECT, ROP WILL CONTINUE TO EXPAND AND IMPROVE ON PREVENTION AND CONTROL OF HIV, VIRAL HEPATITIS, STDS AND TB BY INCREASING KNOWLEDGE, REDUCING NEW INFECTION, REDUCING HEALTH DISPARITIES, AND PROVIDING INTEGRATED SERVICES TO OUR POPULATION.

STRENGTHENING COLLABORATION BETWEEN TB CONTROL PROGRAMS AND AFFILIATED PARTNERS IN THE UNITED STATES: A UNIQUE ROLE FOR NTCA - THE MANAGEMENT OF TB CONTROL ACTIVITIES VARIES WITHIN THE UNITED STATES; IN SOME AREAS, PUBLIC HEALTH CLINICS LEAD THE CHARGE, AND IN AREAS WITH LOW MORBIDITY, THE PRIVATE SECTOR PARTNERS WITH PUBLIC HEALTH CLINICS TO TREAT LATENT TB INFECTION (LTBI). LTBI PREVALENCE DATA ARE CRITICAL TO TRACKING THE UNITED STATES' PROGRESS IN TESTING AND TREATING PERSONS WITH LATENT TB INFECTION. MORE THAN 80% OF TB CASES IN THE US RESULT FROM LONG-STANDING, UNTREATED LATENT TB INFECTION. TB IS A NATIONALLY NOTIFIABLE DISEASE; HOWEVER, LTBI IS NOT REPORTED TO THE CDC SO WE ARE UNABLE TO ASSESS THE PRESENCE OF HEALTH DISPARITIES AMONG THE 13 MILLION PEOPLE ESTIMATED TO HAVE LTBI IN THE US.  HOWEVER, HIGH QUALITY SURVEILLANCE DATA FOR TB DISEASE DOES EXIST AND THESE DATA FROM THE UNITED STATES ARE STRIKING REMINDERS OF THE INHERENT HEALTH INEQUITIES AND DISPARITIES MANY INDIVIDUALS OF COLOR FACE. ACCORDING TO THE 2021 NATIONAL TB SURVEILLANCE REPORT , 89% OF TB CASES REPORTED IN THE US OCCURRED AMONG PERSONS IN RACIAL AND ETHNIC MINORITY GROUPS WHO HISTORICALLY EXPERIENCED DISPARITIES. IN 2021, US STATE, LOCAL, AND TERRITORIAL HEALTH AGENCIES REPORTED 7,860 TB CASES TO THE CDC. TB IN THE ASIAN, BLACK AND HISPANIC/LATINX COMMUNITIES ARE AS FOLLOWS: -	THE TB CASE RATE IS 33 TIMES HIGHER FOR ASIAN PERSONS THAN NON-HISPANIC WHITE PERSONS -	THE TB CASE RATE IS EIGHT TIMES HIGHER FOR NON-HISPANIC BLACK OR AFRICAN AMERICAN THAN NON-HISPANIC WHITE PERSONS -	THE TB CASE RATE IS NINE TIMES HIGHER FOR HISPANIC OR LATINO PERSONS THAN NON-HISPANIC WHITE PERSON.  AS EVIDENCED, TB TELLS A HORRIFIC STORY ON PARALLEL WITH THE IMPACT OF COVID-19 ON PEOPLE OF COLOR. NOTABLY, SOCIAL ISSUES THAT HAVE RISEN TO THE TOP OF OUR COLLECTIVE CONSCIOUSNESS DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC ARE EVERYDAY PROBLEMS ENCOUNTERED BY TB PATIENTS AND THE STAFF WHO PROVIDE TB CARE. TB CASES CONTINUE TO OCCUR AMONG NON-US-BORN PERSONS AT DISPROPORTIONATE RATES; THEREFORE, THE EFFORTS TO ADDRESS THE HEALTH OF MINORITY POPULATIONS, IMMIGRANTS, AND REFUGEES IS ESSENTIAL.  AGAINST THIS DRAMATIC BACKDROP OF SIGNIFICANT INEQUITIES AND DISPARITIES FOR INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES EXPERIENCING TB AND LTBI, THE FOCUS ON SDOH, EFFORTS TO MINIMIZE HEALTH DISPARITIES, AND PROMOTE HEALTH EQUITY IN PS22-2205 IS ESSENTIAL IF THE US IS TO MAKE ANY SUBSTANTIVE PROGRESS TOWARDS TB ELIMINATION.  THE MISSION OF THE NATIONAL TUBERCULOSIS CONTROLLERS ASSOCIATION (NTCA) IS TO PROTECT THE PUBLIC’S HEALTH BY ADVANCING THE ELIMINATION OF TUBERCULOSIS IN THE UNITED STATES THROUGH THE CONCERTED ACTION OF STATE, LOCAL, AND TERRITORIAL PROGRAMS. NTCA, AS THE PROFESSIONAL MEMBER SERVICE ORGANIZATION REPRESENTING PUBLIC HEALTH TB CONTROL PROGRAMS AND THEIR STAFF, IS UNIQUELY QUALIFIED TO FULFILL THE REQUIREMENTS OUTLINED IN, AND SUCCESSFULLY DELIVER THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES EXPECTED FROM, PS22-2205, STRENGTHENING COLLABORATION BETWEEN TB CONTROL PROGRAMS AND AFFILIATED PARTNERS IN THE UNITED STATES. FOUNDED IN 1995, NTCA HAS 25 YEARS OF CONTINUOUS EXPERIENCE PROVIDING LEADERSHIP, EDUCATION, AND TECHNICAL EXPERTISE TO SUPPORT NATIONAL, STATE, TERRITORIAL, AND LOCAL PROGRAMS AND PARTNERSHIPS TO CONTROL TB. NTCA BRINGS TOGETHER EXPERTS FROM TB CONTROL PROGRAMS AND LEADS NATIONAL EFFORTS TO ADVANCE AND ADVOCATE FOR TB CONTROL AND ELIMINATION ACTIVITIES THROUGHOUT THE COUNTY. NTCA’S PERFORMANCE DURING THE CURRENT COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT HAS DEMONSTRATED THE VALUE OF ENGAGING THE NATION’S TB CONTROL PROGRAMS AND AFFILIATED PARTNERS TO SPEAK WITH A COLLECTIVE VOICE ON ISSUES THAT AFFECT THEIR ABILITY TO CONTROL AND ULTIMATELY ELIMINATE TB. THIS EXPANDED WORK TO CONTINUE ADDRESSING TB PROGRAMS’ EDUCATIONAL AND TRAINING NEEDS, WHILE CREATING OPPORTUNITIES FOR PARTNERSHIPS AND COLLABORATIONS TO ADDRESS SDOH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES, WILL MOVE US TOWARDS GREATER HEALTH EQUITY AND, ULTIMATELY, THE ELIMINATION OF TB

FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH STRENGTHENING CIVIL SURGEONS CAPACITY FOR LTBI SURVEILLANCE AND TREATMENT OF STATUS ADJUSTERS APPLICATION - THE REPORTING OF STATUS ADJUSTERS WITH LTBI OFFERS AN OPPORTUNITY TO ASSESS THE FEASIBILITY OF SCALING UP A LTBI REGISTRY SYSTEM, AND TREATMENT OF LTBI WITHIN THIS POPULATION IS SIGNIFICANTLY LIKELY TO REDUCE TB ACTIVATION, PREVENT TB TRANSMISSION, AND BE COST-EFFECTIVE.  FLORIDA IS AN IDEAL SITE TO DEVELOP NEW APPROACHES AND STRATEGIES TO REDUCE BARRIERS CIVIL SURGEONS (CS) FACE IN ADHERING TO THE TECHNICAL INSTRUCTIONS FOR LATENT TUBERCULOSIS. WITH OVER 4.5 MILLION NON-US BORN (USB) INDIVIDUALS MAKING UP 21% OF THE POPULATION OF FLORIDA, ANY INCREASE IN TESTING AND TREATMENT OF LTBI IN THIS HIGH TB RISK POPULATION IS LIKELY TO HAVE NOTICEABLE IMPACT ON THE EPIDEMIOLOGY OF TB. THIS IS PARTICULARLY TRUE IN SOUTH FLORIDA WHERE, AS OF 2019, 53.4 OF MIAMI-DADE COUNTY RESIDENTS (1.45 MILLION PEOPLE) WERE BORN OUTSIDE OF THE U.S., FOUR TIME HIGHER THAN THE NATIONAL AVERAGE OF 13.7%. LTBI IS CURRENTLY NOT REPORTABLE IN FLORIDA, BUT THERE IS A NEED FOR IMPROVED SURVEILLANCE DATA TO MAKE A CASE FOR FUTURE SURVEILLANCE AND DATA COLLECTION TO UNDERSTAND THE BURDEN OF LTBI IN A HIGH NON-USB POPULATION STATE.  THE FLORIDA CIVIL SURGEON TB CONSORTIUM (FCSTC) IS THE FORMALIZATION OF EXISTING INFORMAL RELATIONSHIPS THAT HAVE EXISTED FOR MORE THAN A DECADE BETWEEN THE MIAMI-DADE HEALTH DEPARTMENT, THE FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH TB CONTROL SECTION, FLORIDA TB PHYSICIANS' NETWORK, THE SOUTHEASTERN NATIONAL TB CENTER (SNTC) AT THE UNIVERSITY OF FLORIDA (UF), AND BORINQUEN HEALTH CENTER OF MIAMI. OVER THE LAST DECADE, THE ABOVE LISTED PARTNERS HAVE COLLABORATED ON VARIOUS PROJECTS DIRECTED AT TRAINING THE TB PUBLIC HEALTH WORKFORCE, IMPROVING LTBI ADHERENCE, AND REFUGEE SCREENING. THIS NEW MORE FORMAL COLLABORATION PROPOSES TO IMPROVE REPORTING AND SURVEILLANCE OF LTBI IN CS PRACTICES, USE THE LTBI CASCADE OF CARE TO ESTABLISH A DETAILED KNOWLEDGE BASE OF LTBI AMONG STATUS ADJUSTERS, AND USE THESE COLLABORATIONS TO DEFINE THE EDUCATIONAL GAPS TO IMPROVE COMMUNICATIONS THAT PROMOTE AWARENESS OF LTBI AMONG STATUS ADJUSTERS AND CS.  THE PURPOSE OF FLORIDA CIVIL SURGEON TUBERCULOSIS CONSORTIUM IS TO IDENTIFY GAPS IN THE CASCADE OF CARE AT HIGH VOLUME CS PRACTICES; TO IDENTIFY AND REMOVE PROVIDER-LEVEL BARRIERS TO ADHERENCE TO LTBI TECHNICAL INSTRUCTIONS FOR CS; AND DEVELOP A STRATEGY OF INTERVENTIONS INCLUDING TRAINING, EDUCATION AND CASE MANAGEMENT THAT WILL INCREASE REPORTING OF LTBI AND INCREASE LTBI TESTING AND TREATMENT COMPLETION AMONG STATUS ADJUSTERS AT CS PRACTICES. FLORIDA AIMS TO ALSO PILOT AN ELECTRONIC PORTAL TO ALLOW FOR THE CASE REPORTING OF LTBI-POSITIVE STATUS ADJUSTERS BY CS TO THE STATE OF FLORIDA FOR FURTHER INTERVENTION.

STRENGTHENING CIVIL SURGEONS' CAPACITY TO IMPROVE LTBI SURVEILLANCE AND OUTCOMES AMONG STATUS ADJUSTERS - THIS IS A JOINT PROJECT BETWEEN THE MDH TB AND REFUGEE HEALTH PROGRAMS TO ENHANCE CURRENT LTBI SURVEILLANCE AMONG STATUS ADJUSTERS AND IMPROVE LTBI TREATMENT OUTCOMES. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO BUILD ON ONGOING ENGAGEMENT WITH BETWEEN LOCAL PUBLIC HEALTH, CIVIL SURGEONS, STATUS ADJUSTERS, AND STATE HEALTH DEPARTMENT PROGRAMS TO MEET THE PROJECT GOALS. THE REFUGEE HEALTH PROGRAM, AS THE STATE’S CENTER POINT FOR CIVIL SURGEONS, REFUGEE AND IMMIGRANT HEALTH, AND STATUS ADJUSTMENT GUIDELINES, HAS BEEN ENGAGED IN THIS WORK SINCE 2018. RHP WILL ENHANCE CURRENT REPORTING REQUIREMENTS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND LTBI PREVALENCE AMONG STATUS ADJUSTER POPULATION AND OUTLINE BARRIERS AND CHALLENGES TO ACCESSING LTBI TREATMENT. INTERVENTIONS THAT SEEK TO IMPROVE LTBI EDUCATION AND TREATMENT OUTCOMES WILL BE IMPLEMENTED AND EVALUATED APPROPRIATELY, AND ALL FINDINGS WILL BE CONSISTENTLY SHARED WITH STATE AND NATIONAL PARTNERS.

INCREASING AWARENESS, SURVEILLANCE, AND LATENT TUBERCULOSIS IN STATUS ADJUSTERS AS IDENTIFIED BY CIVIL SURGEONS - IN PARTNERSHIP WITH A LOCAL CIVIL SURGEON, WILLIAMSON COUNTY AND CITIES HEALTH DISTRICT (WCCHD) WILL WORK TO INCREASE LATENT TUBERCULOSIS (LTBI) SURVEILLANCE AND TREATMENT RATES TO PREVENT PROGRESSION TO TUBERCULOSIS (TB) DISEASE IN CLIENTS WHO HAVE IMMIGRATED TO THE UNITED STATES AND ARE APPLYING FOR CITIZENSHIP, ALSO KNOWN AS STATUS ADJUSTERS.  IN COLLABORATION WITH THE CIVIL SURGEON, WCCHD WILL ESTABLISH PROCESSES FOR DATA COLLECTION AND REPORTING OF LTBI CASES AMONG STATUS ADJUSTERS AND SUBMIT CORRESPONDING DATA TO THE CDC. WITH THIS DATA, PRE- AND POST- INTERVENTION CARE CASCADES FOR LTBI WILL BE CREATED ALONG WITH THE DEVELOPMENT OF A SURVEILLANCE SUMMARY REPORT.  ALONG WITH THE CIVIL SURGEON, WCCHD WILL ESTABLISH ADDITIONAL PARTNERSHIPS WITH VARIOUS COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS AND STATUS ADJUSTERS TO FORM A STAKEHOLDER GROUP TO IDENTIFY, DEVELOP, AND PLAN FOR INTERVENTION IMPLEMENTATIONS AND EVALUATION WITH USE OF A GAP ANALYSIS. THIS WILL LEAD TO PRODUCTION OF AN INTERVENTION EVALUATION REPORT.  WCCHD CURRENTLY SEES A LARGE POPULATION OF LTBI CLIENTS, PRIMARILY THOSE WHO ARE FOREIGN BORN. MANY CLIENTS ARE UNINSURED OR LOW-INCOME. REFERRALS COME FROM A VARIETY OF SOURCES INCLUDING CIVIL SURGEONS, PRIVATE PRACTICE PROVIDERS AND HOSPITALS. BY ENGAGING WITH LOCAL CIVIL SURGEONS, WCCHD WILL INCREASE CAPACITY TO IDENTIFY, MONITOR,EDUCATE, AND EXPEDITE CONNECTIONS TO TREATMENT TO PREVENT TB DISEASE IN A HIGH-RISK POPULATION AND CONTRIBUTE TO THE OVERALL ELIMINATION OF TB.

STRENGTHENING CIVIL SURGEON'S CAPACITY TO IMPROVE LTBI SURVEILLANCE AND OUTCOMES AMONG STATUS ADJUSTORS IN CALIFORNIA - THIS PROPOSAL OUTLINES A TWO-YEAR PROJECT FOCUSED ON STRENGTHENING CIVIL SURGEONS’ CAPACITY TO IMPROVE LATENT TUBERCULOSIS INFECTION (LTBI) SURVEILLANCE AND OUTCOMES AMONG IMMIGRATION STATUS ADJUSTERS IN ORANGE COUNTY, CALIFORNIA. IN 2021, THE COUNTY REPORTED THE THIRD HIGHEST NUMBER OF TUBERCULOSIS (TB) CASES IN THE STATE AND CIVIL SURGEONS IN THE COUNTY REPORTED MORE THAN 265 STATUS ADJUSTERS WITH POSITIVE IGRA RESULTS. MOST PEOPLE WHO HAVE LTBI ARE NOT AWARE OF THEIR TB INFECTION AND ONLY 12% HAVE BEEN TREATED. COMPLETING A FULL COURSE OF LTBI TREATMENT WILL PREVENT PROGRESSION TO INFECTIOUS TB DISEASE, AND IS THE ONLY WAY TO PREVENT THIS DEBILITATING AND EXPENSIVE DISEASE.  THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO STRENGTHEN CIVIL SURGEONS’ CAPACITY TO IMPROVE LTBI SURVEILLANCE AND CARE OUTCOMES AMONG IMMIGRATION STATUS ADJUSTERS.  TWO STRATEGIES WILL BE UTILIZED: 1) EXPANDING SURVEILLANCE OF LTBI AMONG STATUS ADJUSTERS; AND 2) IMPLEMENTING INTERVENTIONS TO ADDRESS IDENTIFIED BARRIERS TO LTBI CARE WHICH CHALLENGE BOTH CIVIL SURGEONS AND STATUS ADJUSTERS.  THE ULTIMATE PROJECT OUTCOME IS TO OPTIMIZE THE LTBI CARE CONTINUUM AS A TOOL TO IMPROVE STATUS ADJUSTER OUTCOMES AND PREVENT FUTURE TB DISEASE IN THIS IMPORTANT TB RISK GROUP.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES FOR STRATEGY 1, THE EXPANSION OF LTBI SURVEILLANCE,  INCLUDE: I) IMPROVED DATA COLLECTION AMONG STATUS ADJUSTORS WITH LTBI; II) ESTABLISHED PRE- AND POST-INTERVENTION LTBI CARE CASCADES FOR THIS POPULATION; AND III) IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF GAPS IN THESE CARE CASCADES WHICH CAN BE ADDRESSED BY INTERVENTIONS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES FOR STRATEGY 2, THE PROGRAMMATIC INTERVENTIONS, INCLUDE: I) TAILORED INTERVENTIONS BASED ON THE FINDINGS OF A GAP ANALYSIS; II) AN INCREASE IN CIVIL SURGEONS LINKING STATUS ADJUSTERS TO LTBI CARE; AND III) INCREASED TREATMENT INITIATION AND COMPLETION AMONG STATUS ADJUSTERS WITH LTBI.  PROPOSED PROJECT ACTIVITIES FOR STRATEGY 1 INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING: I) COLLECT AND REPORT DE-IDENTIFIED INDIVIDUAL-LEVEL LTBI-RELATED AND AGGREGATE DATA FOR ALL STATUS ADJUSTERS WHO PRESENT FOR A MEDICAL EXAM WITH HIGH-VOLUME CIVIL SURGEONS; II) GENERATE PRE- AND POST-INTERVENTION LTBI CARE CASCADES; AND 3) DEVELOP A SURVEILLANCE SUMMARY REPORT. FOR STRATEGY 2, THE INITIAL INTERVENTION WILL BE TO CONDUCT A GAP ANALYSIS TO IDENTIFY INTERVENTION NEEDS. THIS ANALYSIS WILL INFORM THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF INTERVENTIONS FOR THIS STRATEGY. POSSIBLE INTERVENTIONS INCLUDE: I) DEVELOPMENT OF A CIVIL SURGEON LTBI TOOLBOX; II) DEVELOP/MODIFY LTBI EDUCATION MATERIALS FOR STATUS ADJUSTORS; III) CONDUCT LTBI TRAINING FOR CIVIL SURGEONS; AND IV) PROMOTE AND ENSURE ACCESSIBILITY OF CLINICAL CONSULTATION RESOURCES FOR THESE PHYSICIANS. A PROJECT EVALUATION PLAN PROVIDES AN OUTLINE OF HOW THE INTERVENTIONS WILL BE MEASURED TO ASSESS SUCCESS.  THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH TB CONTROL BRANCH (TBCB) WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE ORANGE COUNTY TB PROGRAM, A HIGH-VOLUME CIVIL SURGEON IN THE COUNTY, AND OTHER HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS TO DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT THIS PROJECT. TBCB HAS BOTH EDUCATIONAL AND TRAINING RESOURCES THAT CAN BE APPROPRIATELY MODIFIED FOR THIS PROJECT, AND THE ORANGE COUNTY TB PROGRAM ALREADY HAS AN ESTABLISHED RELATIONSHIP WITH THE HIGH-VOLUME CIVIL SURGEON WHO HAS AGREED TO COLLABORATE.
TUBERCULOSIS ELIMINATION AND LABORATORY COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT - 2020
SAN FRANCISCO TUBERCULOSIS ELIMINATION AND LABORATORY COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT APPLICATION

ACCELERATING THE PREVENTION AND CONTROL OF HIV, VIRAL HEPATITIS, STDS AND TB IN THE U.S.-AFFILIATED PACIFIC ISLANDS - 2018
THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL ENHANCE AND STRENGTHEN GUAM'S HIV, VIRAL HEPATITIS, STDS AND TUBERCULOSIS PROGRAMS SO EFFECTIVE AND TIMELY PUBLIC HEALTH RESPONSES WILL REDUCE MORBIDITY AND MORTALITY.
RMI MINISTRY OF HEALTH PROGRAM COLLABORATION SERVICE INTEGRATION ON HIV/STI, TB & VIRAL HEPATITIS 5YEAR PROJECT

TO ACCELERATE THE PREVENTION AND CONTROL OF HIV, VIRAL HEPATITIS, SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED DISEASE AND TUBERCULOSIS IN THE FEDERATED STATES OF MICRONESIA AND U.S. PACIFIC ISLANDS - ACCELERATING THE PREVENTION AND CONTROL OF HIV, VIRAL HEPATITIS, STD AND TUBERCULOSIS IN THE FEDERATED STATES OF MICRONESIA IS A PRIORITY AS THESE FOUR FOCUS DISEASE AREAS ARE STILL MAJOR HEALTH ISSUES IN THE COUNTRY. HIV IS LOW BUT STD RATES FOR CHLAMYDIA AND SYPHILIS REMAINS HIGH. THE PROGRAM COLLABORATION AND SERVICE INTEGRATION PROJECT WITH ITS 4 STRATEGIES WILL IMPROVE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF PROGRAM IMPLEMENTATION AND SERVICE DELIVERY. THE COLLABORATION OF PROGRAMS WILL LEAD TO IMPROVEMENT IN PATIENT CARE AND MANAGEMENT FOR MULTIPLE DISEASES. THIS PROGRAM COLLABORATION AND SERVICE INTEGRATION IS APPROPRIATE AND EFFECTIVE FOR AREAS WITH GEOGRAPHIC AND LIMITED HUMAN RESOURCE CHALLENGES, CROSS TRAINING OF STAFF WILL ALSO LEAD TO INCREASED KNOWLEDGE IN MULTIPLE DISEASES.  THIS PROJECT WILL LEAD TO IMPROVED PREVENTION ACTIVITIES AND PATIENT OUTCOMES. DATA MANAGEMENT AND DISEASE SURVEILLANCE WILL IMPROVE THE DECISION MAKING FROM HIGHER MANAGEMENT AND GUIDE THE PROGRAMS IN USE OF FUNDING SOURCES. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO SUPPORT STREAMLINE INTEGRATED INTERVENTIONS LEADING TO DECREASING RATES OF DISEASES.
